org.chronos.chronosphere.api.query

Interface QueryStepBuilder<S,E>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.util.Iterator<E>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    EObjectQueryStepBuilder<S>, NumericCastableQueryStepBuilder<S,E>, NumericQueryStepBuilder<S,E>, QueryStepBuilderInternal<S,E>, UntypedQueryStepBuilder<S,E>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractQueryStepBuilder, EObjectQueryStepBuilderImpl, NumericQueryStepBuilderImpl, ObjectQueryStepBuilderImpl

    public interface QueryStepBuilder<S,E>
extends java.util.Iterator<E>

    • Method Summary

    • Method Detail

      • filter

        QueryStepBuilder<S,E> filter(java.util.function.Predicate<E> predicate)
        Applies the given filter predicate to all elements in the current result.
        Parameters:
        predicate - The predicate to apply. Must not be null. All elements for which the predicate function returns false will be filtered out and discarded.
        Returns:
        The query builder, for method chaining. Never null.

      • limit

        QueryStepBuilder<S,E> limit(long limit)
        Limits the number of elements in the result set to the given number.

        Please note that the order of elements is in general arbitrary. Therefore, usually a limit(long) is preceded by a orderBy(Comparator).

        Parameters:
        limit - The limit to apply. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        The query builder, for method chaining. Never null.

      • orderBy

        QueryStepBuilder<S,E> orderBy(java.util.Comparator<E> comparator)
        Sorts the current result set by applying the given comparator.

        This method requires full resolution of all elements and is therefore non-lazy.

        Parameters:
        comparator - The comparator to use. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The query builder, for method chaining. Never null.

      • distinct

        QueryStepBuilder<S,E> distinct()
        Eliminates all duplicated values from the current result.

        This method is lazy, but requires to keep track of the "already encountered" elements in a set. Therefore, RAM consumption on this method may be high if it is applied on very large result sets.

        Returns:
        The distinct step builder, for method chaining. Never null.

      • map

        <T> UntypedQueryStepBuilder<S,T> map(java.util.function.Function<E,T> function)
        Uses the given function to map each element from the current result set to a new element.
        Parameters:
        function - The mapping function to apply. Must not be null. Should be idempotent and side-effect free.
        Returns:
        The query step builder, for method chaining. Never null.

      • flatMap

        <T> UntypedQueryStepBuilder<S,T> flatMap(java.util.function.Function<E,java.util.Iterator<T>> function)
        Uses the given function to map each element to an iterator of output elements. These output iterators will be concatenated and forwarded.
        Parameters:
        function - The map function to apply. Must not be null. Should be idempotent and side-effect free.
        Returns:
        The query step builder, for method chaining. Never null.

      • notNull

        QueryStepBuilder<S,E> notNull()
        Filters out and discards all null values from the current result set.

        This is the same as: 

         query.filter(element -> element != null)
        Returns:
        The query step builder, for method chaining. Never null.
        See Also:
        filter(Predicate)

      • named

        QueryStepBuilder<S,E> named(java.lang.String stepName)
        Assigns the given name to this QueryStepBuilder.

        Note that only the step is named. When coming back to this step, the query result may be different than it was when it was first reached, depending on the traversal.

        Parameters:
        stepName - The name of the step. Must not be null. Must be unique within the query.
        Returns:
        The named step, for method chaining. Never null.
        See Also:
        back(String)

      • back

        UntypedQueryStepBuilder<S,java.lang.Object> back(java.lang.String stepName)
        Exits the current traversal state and goes back to a named step, or a named set.
        Parameters:
        stepName - The name of the step to go back to. Must not be null, must refer to a named step.
        Returns:
        The step after going back, for method chaining. Never null.
        See Also:
        named(String)

      • except

        QueryStepBuilder<S,E> except(java.lang.String stepName)
        Removes all elements from the given named step from this step.
        Parameters:
        stepName - The name of the step. Must not be null, must refer to a named step.
        Returns:
        The step after removing the elements in the given named step, for method chaining. Never null.

      • except

        QueryStepBuilder<S,E> except(java.util.Set<?> elementsToExclude)
        Removes all elements in the given set from the stream.
        Parameters:
        elementsToExclude - The elements to remove. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The step after removing the elements in the given set, for method chaining. Never null.

      • union

        UntypedQueryStepBuilder<S,java.lang.Object> union(QueryStepBuilder<E,?>... subqueries)

      • and

        QueryStepBuilder<S,E> and(QueryStepBuilder<E,?>... subqueries)

      • or

        QueryStepBuilder<S,E> or(QueryStepBuilder<E,?>... subqueries)

      • not

        QueryStepBuilder<S,E> not(QueryStepBuilder<E,?> subquery)

      • toSet

        java.util.Set<E> toSet()
        Calculates the result set of this query and returns it.

        Please note that iterating over the result set via Iterator.hasNext() and Iterator.next() is in general faster and consumes less RAM than first converting the result into a set.

        Returns:
        The result set. Never null. May be empty.

      • toList

        java.util.List<E> toList()
        Calculates the result of this query and returns it as a List.

        Please note that iterating over the result via Iterator.hasNext() and Iterator.next() is in general faster and consumes less RAM than first converting the result into a list.

        Returns:
        The result list. Never null. May be empty.

      • toStream

        java.util.stream.Stream<E> toStream()
        Converts this query into a Stream.
        Returns:
        The stream representation of this query.

      • count

        long count()
        Counts the number of elements in the current result, and returns that count.
        Returns:
        The count. Never negative, may be zero.
